controls.description: Configuration standards for network security controls are defined, implemented, and maintained to restrict inbound and outbound traffic to that which is necessary for the cardholder data environment.
Inbound traffic to the cardholder data environment is restricted to only necessary and authorized communications, and all other traffic is specifically denied.

Configuration standards are developed, implemented, and maintained for all system components that address all known security vulnerabilities and are consistent with industry-accepted system hardening standards.
Primary account numbers are rendered unreadable anywhere they are stored by implementing cryptographic mechanisms using strong cryptography with associated key-management processes and procedures.
Strong cryptography and security protocols are implemented to safeguard primary account numbers during transmission over open, public networks.

Software engineering techniques or other methods are defined and in use by software development personnel to prevent or mitigate common software attacks and related vulnerabilities in bespoke and custom software.
Security vulnerabilities are identified and managed through the installation of applicable security patches and updates to all software components.
An access control model is defined and includes granting access based on the principle of least privilege and need-to-know for each user or system component.
Access is assigned to users, including privileged users, based on job classification and function with the minimum privileges necessary to perform job responsibilities.
All user access to system components for users and administrators is authenticated via at least one authentication factor including passwords, tokens, smart cards, or biometrics.
If passwords or passphrases are used as authentication factors, they meet a minimum level of complexity including a minimum length of 12 characters containing both numeric and alphabetic characters.
Audit logs are enabled and active for all system components and cardholder data to support the detection, alerting, and analysis of security events.

Audit logs record sufficient details for each auditable event including user identification, event type, date and time, success or failure indication, origination of event, and identity or name of affected data, system component, resource, or service.
Internal vulnerability scans are performed at least once every three months and after any significant change. High-risk and critical vulnerabilities are resolved and rescans confirm resolution.
An overall information security policy is established, published, maintained, and disseminated to all relevant personnel and vendors.
